title: support running on demeter
support running on google cloud
no good calls in local-wgs1 benchmark
body:
For the local-wgs1 benchmark, we seem to have no variants in common between the published variants and the guacamole called variants. This is a bug somewhere.

```
(analysis-venv-2.7)[tim@Tims-MacBook ~/sinai/git/variant-calling-benchmarks]$ cat results/summary.local-wgs1.csv
stat,comparison_dataset,numerator,denominator,percent
calls,,10,,
calls before filtering,,392,,
calls,published,322,,
sensitivity with filters,published,0,322.0,0.0
specificity with filters,published,0,10.0,0.0
sensitivity from pooled calling only without filters,published,0,322.0,0.0
sensitivity individual calling only without filters,published,0,322.0,0.0
specificity without filters,published,0,392.0,0.0
specificity both pooled and individual triggers firing,published,0,373.0,0.0
```

title: Add PT189 benchmark
body:
The first issue here will be to get guacamole to succeed on all PT189 samples. Then we can compare against mutect / strelka individual sample calls.

Hammer lab folks, more details on this internal issue: https://github.com/hammerlab/projects/issues/29

title: Document benchmark.json
body:
Is there some documentation on what `benchmark.json` should be?

By inspection, it seems that one benchmark to correspond to one file of validated variants?  It can support multiple patients, but gold-standard variants should be in a single file?

title: specificity computation
body:
Looking in `joint_caller.py` the specificity computation is 

```
merged.ix[merged.called_guacamole][called_col]
```

This seems like this computes the number of true calls / number of calls made by guacamole - is that's what intended? Should this be precision then or do I have that wrong?

title: figure out how to test, setup travis and coveralls
body:
To run a full benchmark we'd need to have travis download and build guacamole. Or maybe we publish and update guacamole jars somewhere that can be downloaded? (If they're way outdated I think it'd be better to use guacamole master.)

An alternative would be to check in some guacamole output VCFs and at least test that the post processing logic works as intended.

title: setup a nightly run
body:
On either demeter or google cloud:
- Check out and build latest guacamole
- Run all benchmarks
- Stash results somewhere, keyed by guacamole git ref and variant-calling-benchmarks git ref
- Email results to guacamole developers

Anyone interested in taking a stab at this?

title: local run example is wrong, uses outdated guacamole-with-dependencies jar
body:
In the readme this run:

```
vcb-guacamole-local \
    base_config.json \
    infrastructure-configs/local.json \
    guacamole-configs/default.json \
    benchmarks/local-wgs1/benchmark.json \
    --guacamole-jar ~/sinai/git/guacamole/target/guacamole-with-dependencies-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar \
    --out-dir results
```

Is actually using an old guacamole jar from before some pom changes. It should actually take both a guacamole jar and a guacamole deps jar, since these are separate jars now.

title: consider better ways of specifying guacamole jars
body: @ryan-williams noted in https://github.com/hammerlab/variant-calling-benchmarks/pull/23 that we may want to consider simpler ways of specifying the two guacamole jars than by a full path to each. For example we could specify just a guacamole checkout path and VCB could know what jars to use in that

title: A somatic reference standard for cancer genome sequencing
body:
http://www.nature.com/articles/srep24607

> performed paired PCR-free whole genome sequencing of a matched metastatic melanoma cell line (COLO829) and normal across three lineages and across separate institutions, with independent library preparations, sequencing, and analysis. We generated mean mapped coverages of 99X for COLO829 and 103X for the paired normal across three institutions.
> 
> common events include >35,000 point mutations, 446 small insertion/deletions, and >6,000 genes affected by copy number changes. We present this reference to the community as an initial standard for enabling quantitative evaluation of somatic mutation pipelines across institutions.
> 
> All BAMs and VCFs, including that for the final somatic reference, can be accessed through NCBI’s (National Center for Biotechnology Information) dbGaP (database of Genotypes and Phenotypes; accession number phs000932) and the European Bioinformatics Institute (EGA (European Genome-phenome Archive) accession number EGAS00001001385).
